status_details: Gov. Mike Dunleavy, a Republican, eased restrictions on several kinds of businesses starting April 24. Alaska became one of the first states to make a nearly complete reopening, with all businesses allowed to open at full capacity on May 22.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, etc.

status_details: Gov. Kay Ivey, a Republican, ordered residents to stay home for much of April and began reopening businesses starting in May. Ms. Ivey extended the state’s “Safer at Home” status and implemented a mask requirement until the end of July.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Entertainment venues
opened_personal_care: Salons

status_details: Gov. Asa Hutchinson, a Republican, never implemented a statewide stay-at-home order, instead opting to close high-contact businesses like gyms and personal care services. The state began reopening many of these in early May. Arkansas has seen one of the steepest increases in coronavirus cases since reopening. In response, Mr. Hutchinson implemented a mask mandate effective July 20.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Theaters, stadiums, museums, bowling alleys; Casinos; Large venues
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, etc.

status_details: After Gov. Doug Ducey’s stay-at-home order expired May 15, Arizona saw cases soar. In late June, Mr. Ducey, a Republican, announced that the state would “pause” operations of bars, gyms, movie theaters, waterparks and tubing rentals to contain the virus’s spread.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools, spas
opened_entertainment: Casinos
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, salons, etc.

status_details: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, emphasized caution as he allowed counties to reopen sectors in May and June. As cases rose in June and July, however, Mr. Newsom backtracked, ordering statewide closures of bars and indoor activities in many sectors including dining and entertainment. The state is also keeping a “watch list” of counties with upward virus trends.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms in some counties
opened_entertainment: Casinos in some areas; Zoos in some counties
closed_entertainment: Movie theaters; Museums, galleries, and aquariums; Arcades and bowling alleys
opened_houses_of_worship: Houses of worship in some counties
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Hair salons and barbershops in some counties; Nail salons, cosmetology services, tattoo parlors, piercing shops in some counties
opened_industries: Manufacturing; Warehouses; Offices in some counties; Movie, TV and music production

status_details: Gov. Jared Polis was one of the first Democratic governors to begin reopening his state, letting Colorado’s stay-at-home order expire on April 26. Businesses reopened throughout May and June, but in response to continuing outbreaks in neighboring states, in July, Mr. Polis extended the state’s “Safer at Home” phase and closed bars. He is allowing some regions to reopen bars and loosen restrictions.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Pools, playgrounds; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Museums, indoor events; Fairs, rodeos, concerts, outdoor events; Libraries
opened_personal_care: Salons and personal services

status_details: Connecticut was one of the last states to begin reopening, on May 20. Gov. Ned Lamont, a Democrat, moved up a second phase of reopening in June after a favorable downward trend in case numbers. But Mr. Lamont postponed a third phase in response to rising cases in neighboring states.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms; State campgrounds
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Casinos; Movie theaters; Libraries; Amusement parks, bowling alleys
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons; Tattoo parlors, spas

status_details: Washington, D.C., was under one of the nation’s strictest lockdowns until reopening on May 29. On June 22,  Mayor Muriel Bowser, a Democrat, opened a second round of businesses. On July 24, she signed an order requiring masks.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Dog parks, golf courses, tennis courts, parks; Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Museums, libraries
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons; Nail salons, waxing salons, spas

status_details: Gov. John Carney, a Democrat, has overseen one of the slower reopenings, beginning June 1 with a limited number of businesses. After an increase in cases, Mr. Carney decided to delay the start of Phase 3, which was scheduled for the end of June.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Pools; Gyms; Campgrounds
opened_entertainment: Museums, libraries, galleries, live performances; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Farmers markets; Restaurants; Bars in some areas
opened_personal_care: Barber shops, hair salons, tanning salons; Nail salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy

status_details: Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, gradually opened businesses in May, starting in Florida’s less populous counties. In early June, he moved forward with reopening bars and larger entertainment venues in some counties, even as case counts rose. On June 26, he moved to effectively shutter bars again after a spike in cases.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches, trails; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Sporting venues without spectators; Museums, libraries; Movie theaters, concert halls, bowling alleys in most counties
opened_personal_care: Salons; Tattoo parlors, massage therapy, tanning salons, acupuncture in most counties

status_details: Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, went toe-to-toe with the White House and local mayors over his decision to reopen large parts of Georgia’s economy ahead of other states. Mr. Kemp has continued steadily with reopening plans while case counts have trended upward, and he has pushed back on local governments that have tried to enforce stricter shutdowns or mask requirements, going as far as suing Atlanta’s mayor and city council over a mask order.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms
opened_entertainment: Bowling alleys; Theaters, private social clubs; Large venues; Bars, nightclubs
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, etc.

status_details: Gov. David Ige, a Democrat, started the state’s reopening process in early May, when there were only a few new cases reported each day. Each island can now set its own timeline for reopening, with the governor’s approval. Despite the slow approach, Hawaii has seen a resurgence of the virus in recent days.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches, piers, docks, etc.; State parks; Pools and waterparks in some areas; Campgrounds in some areas; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Arcades, bowling alleys, theaters in some areas
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Nail salons in some areas; Tattoo parlors in some areas; Salons and barbershops
opened_industries: Construction in some areas; Offices in some areas

status_details: Gov. Kim Reynolds, a Republican, ordered a number of businesses to close in March, but did not issue a stay-at-home order. Ms. Reynolds began loosening restrictions on May 1, and capacity limits on businesses were lifted in June.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms; Pools; Playgrounds, skating rinks, skate parks
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Movie theaters; Museums, zoos, aquariums; Casinos; Outdoor venues; Bowling alleys, amusement parks; Indoor venues
opened_personal_care: Medical spas, tanning salons; Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.

status_details: Gov. Brad Little, a Republican, began his state’s four-stage reopening process on May 1. Idaho moved through the first three stages of reopening swiftly, but as cases surged, Mr. Little delayed a full reopening planned for June 26. After a two-week delay, on July 9, he announced the state would remain in its final stage of reopening for at least another two weeks.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools and water parks
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Nightclubs; Large venues
opened_personal_care: Hair salons

status_details: Gov. J.B. Pritzker, a Democrat, faced political pushback for his cautious reopening strategy, but Illinois has not seen a strong upward trend in cases. On June 26, the state moved into its fourth and final stage of reopening.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; limited fishing, boating, golf courses; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Theaters
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming; Hair salons, barber shops, nail salons, spas, waxing centers, tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Eric Holcomb, a Republican, eased restrictions and allowed some reopenings beginning in early May. In July, citing an increase in cases, Mr. Holcomb paused progress toward the final stage of reopening. He later required face masks in most public settings beginning July 27.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools, tennis and basketball courts; Campgrounds; Amusement parks, water parks
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Museums, zoos and aquariums; Venues; Movie theaters; Bowling alleys; Conventions, fairs, parades and similar events in most counties
opened_personal_care: Spas, salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors

status_details: After reopening began May 4, Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, faced backlash from Republicans in the state legislature who wanted the process to move more quickly. She vetoed a measure seeking to curb her emergency powers, and allowed reopenings at the discretion of individual counties. Ms. Kelly ordered Kansans to wear masks in public beginning July 3.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Community centers, sports facilities; Pools
opened_entertainment: Theaters, museums and bowling alleys; Casinos; Nightclubs
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Andy Beshear, a Democrat, reopened businesses under new guidelines beginning in early May, then ordered residents to wear masks in public soon after the state had reached the end of its initial reopening timeline. As case numbers continued to climb, Mr. Beshear ordered bars to close again starting July 28 and restaurants to reduce indoor dining capacity to 25 percent.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Aquatic centers; Campgrounds; Public pools
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums, aquariums, libraries, outdoor attractions; Venues and events spaces
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming and boarding; Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.

status_details: Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, allowed the state’s stay-at-home order to lift and an array of businesses to reopen starting May 15. In June, citing an increase in cases, Mr. Edwards said the state would remain in Phase 2 for several more weeks. As cases continued to climb, Mr. Edwards ordered bars to close again and required the use of masks in public.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; State parks; Pools; Bowling alleys, skating rinks
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Certain museums, zoos and aquariums; Casinos; Event centers
opened_personal_care: Salons and barbershops; Spas, tattoo parlors
closed_outdoor_and_recreation: Amusement parks, water parks and theme parks; Concert and music halls

status_details: Gov. Charlie Baker, a Republican, announced a phased reopening beginning in May. The state is now in the third phase. Mr. Baker has indicated that the fourth and final phase, which would allow bars to reopen, will not begin until a treatment or vaccine is available.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; Beaches, parks, fishing, hunting and boating; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Bowling alleys; Museums, aquariums; Theaters and performance venues; Movie theaters; Casinos
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Pet grooming; Nail salons, massage parlors, tanning salons

status_details: Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican who has called for an aggressive response to the virus, allowed some businesses to open with social distancing requirements starting May 15, but encouraged the adoption of more restrictive local guidelines as needed.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, outdoor shooting ranges, marinas, campgrounds; Beaches; Outdoor pools and day camps; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Outdoor service at breweries, wineries, and distilleries; Restaurants; Bars
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, massage parlors, tanning salons, tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Janet Mills, a Democrat, allowed some businesses to begin reopening statewide in May and allowed additional, accelerated reopenings in counties with few coronavirus cases. More businesses were allowed to reopen statewide in June, but further reopenings, including of bars, have been delayed.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks, boating, golf courses; Remote campgrounds, hunting and fishing; Private campgrounds, RV parks; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Amusement parks, water parks; Bowling alleys and arcades; Movie theaters; Performing arts venues; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurants; Bars open for outdoor service
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, pet groomers; Nail salons and tattoo parlors; Spas and massage parlors

status_details: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, took a regional approach to reopening before lifting Michigan's stay-at-home order on June 1. Ms. Whitmer has since paused further reopenings, and on July 1, she ordered bars in most of the state to close again for indoor service. She later mandated the use of masks in most public settings.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, marinas; Pools; Gyms in some regions
opened_entertainment: Arcades, bowling alleys, theaters, night clubs and convention centers in some regions
opened_food_and_drink: Bars for indoor service in certain counties; Restaurant dining; Bars for outdoor service
closed_food_and_drink: Bars for indoor service in certain counties
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors
opened_industries: Construction, real estate; Manufacturing, including auto companies; Offices

status_details: Gov. Tim Walz, a Democrat, first allowed employees in certain agriculture, industrial and office settings to return to work in late April. More businesses were allowed to open after his stay-at-home order expired in May. Mr. Walz later ordered the use of face masks in most public settings beginning July 25.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Theaters and concert halls; Bowling alleys, arcades and museums
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, reopened all businesses in early May, with social distancing requirements, and lifted all restrictions on June 16. Since then, Missouri has seen several record-setting single-day increases in coronavirus cases.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Campgrounds
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, music venues, etc.; Casinos
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.

status_details: Gov. Tate Reeves, a Republican, let the state’s stay-at-home order expire April 27 and reopened retail stores, with some limits. All businesses were allowed to open June 1. In July, Mr. Reeves announced that the state would pause a full reopening. As numbers continued to climb, Mr. Reeves gradually imposed mask orders in dozens of counties, in addition to tightening restrictions on social gatherings and bars statewide.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Casinos; Movie theaters; Libraries, museums
opened_personal_care: Salons and barbershops; Tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Steve Bullock, a Democrat, allowed reopening in phases, beginning in late April. All businesses could reopen June 1, provided they followed certain guidelines. In July, citing rising case counts, Mr. Bullock ordered Montanans in certain counties to wear masks in many public settings.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms
opened_entertainment: Museums, movie theaters; Concert venues; Bowling alleys; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining, bars, breweries and distilleries
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, massage parlors

status_details: Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat, allowed a variety of businesses to reopen in May. In late June, with cases counts trending upward, Mr. Cooper paused North Carolina’s reopening plan and required residents to wear face coverings in public.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Doug Burgum, a Republican, never issued a stay-at-home order, and allowed a variety of businesses to reopen starting May 1.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Sports venues
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Music and entertainment venues
opened_personal_care: Salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.

status_details: Gov. Pete Ricketts, a Republican, never issued a stay-at-home order, but he put in place several restrictions on businesses. Mr. Ricketts announced a plan to reopen certain businesses on a regional basis starting in early May. All counties have been in Phase 3, which allows for restaurants and bars to return to full capacity, since early July.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Zoos, movie theaters, libraries and venues
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.

status_details: Gov. Chris Sununu, a Republican, gradually reopened sectors starting in mid-May. On June 15, he allowed his stay-at-home order to expire and reopened businesses on a rolling basis. The final round of businesses reopened, with capacity limits and social distancing guidance, on June 29.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; Outdoor attractions; Beaches; Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Libraries, museums, art galleries; Bowling alleys and entertainment centers; Movie theaters; Amusement parks; Live performances
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons, etc.; Nail salons; Tanning salons; Tattoo shops; Acupuncturists and massage therapists

status_details: Gov. Phil Murphy, a Democrat, was one of the last governors to lift a stay-at-home order, on June 9. New Jersey cautiously reopened businesses over the course of May and June, and rolling reopenings were set to continue into July. After indefinitely delaying plans to reopen indoor dining early in the month, Mr. Murphy announced in mid-July that the state would pause in its current phase of reopening.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; Beaches; Campgrounds; Gyms for personal training; Pools
opened_entertainment: Libraries for curbside pickup; Casinos; Playgrounds, water parks, amusement parks; Museums, libraries, aquariums; Bowling alleys, batting cages, shooting ranges
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, tattoo parlors, spas, massage therapy, tanning salons

status_details: Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat, allowed some sectors to reopen May 16. As cases rose, Ms. Grisham announced she would delay the next phase of reopening indefinitely, and later ordered restaurants to restrict indoor dining.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Golf courses, boating; Gyms, pools
closed_food_and_drink: Bars; Restaurant dining; Indoor service at breweries
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming and boarding, veterinary services; Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, massage parlors, nail salons

status_details: Gov. Steve Sisolak, a Democrat, kept pace with other states and reopened businesses throughout May. Casinos and gaming were allowed to resume operations on June 4. In response to a recent spike in cases, Mr. Sisolak tabled plans for Phase 3 and is now requiring Nevadans to wear face masks.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, pickleball, tennis courts; State parks; Gyms; Pools and water parks
opened_entertainment: Museums, art galleries, zoos and aquariums; Movie theaters, bowling alleys; Gaming
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons and nail salons; Massage therapy; Tattoo and piercing shops

status_details: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, announced limited and phased reopenings by region starting May 15. New York City, the hardest-hit region in the state, became the last to enter Phase 4 of reopening on July 20. But unlike in other regions, indoor dining at restaurants remains prohibited and other indoor venues, like shopping malls, will stay closed in New York City.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Fishing and hunting; Public pools and playgrounds; Outdoor zoos, botanical gardens and nature parks
opened_entertainment: Museums and aquariums in some regions

closed_entertainment: Movie theaters, casinos; Amusement parks, bowling alleys

status_details: Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, lifted a stay-at-home order on May 1 and allowed businesses to reopen in phases, starting with retail stores, salons and restaurants. In July, Mr. DeWine asked several counties to limit activities as much as possible, though he did not order any closures. Starting July 23, the use of face masks became mandatory statewide in both indoor and outdoor public spaces.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms, pools, and sports leagues; Bowling alleys, miniature golf and batting cages; Aquariums, zoos; Skating rinks, playgrounds, country clubs
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, museums, art galleries; Casinos, racinos, amusement parks, water parks
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.

status_details: Gov. Kevin Stitt, a Republican, implemented a three-phase approach to reopening businesses starting April 24. Phase 3 began in June, when all restrictions were lifted on businesses and group gatherings provided people “consider social distancing.”
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Zoos; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, sports venues, museums; Nightclubs
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, spas, pet groomers, etc.; Tattoo parlors

status_details: Gov. Kate Brown, a Democrat, started a three-phase regional reopening on May 15, but Ms. Brown said Phase 3 would not come until September at the earliest. Masks are required in both outdoor and indoor spaces, and indoor gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited. Capacity for restaurants and bars was lowered July 24.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Some state parks; Pools in most counties; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, bowling alleys in most counties
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops

status_details: Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, took a county-by-county approach to shutting down and took a similar approach to reopening, allowing counties to open in phases. By July 3, all of the state was in the last phase of reopening, but wearing a mask is now required in all public places. Starting July 16, indoor dining was reduced to 25 percent capacity, and bars could open only for restaurant service.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, marinas, private campgrounds; Beaches; State parks; Public pools; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Casinos, theaters
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, spas

status_details: Gov. Wanda Vázquez announced a curfew and closed non-essential businesses in March. Restaurants and retail stores were allowed to reopen in late May. In mid-June, Ms. Vázquez eased the lockdown and allowed most businesses to reopen, but on July 17, she ordered the re-closure of bars, movie theaters, casinos and gyms and reduced indoor dining limits to 50 percent.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches
opened_entertainment: Museums; Outdoor concerts and other open venues
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops; Pet grooming

status_details: Gov. Gina Raimondo, a Democrat, announced a three-phase reopening plan starting with retail stores after her stay-at-home order lifted on May 8. Rhode Island entered its second phase of reopening in June, with restaurants, gyms, salons and beaches allowed to open. The third phase began June 30, though the governor decided to limit indoor social gatherings to 25 people.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Beaches; Gyms; Casinos; Campgrounds
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, massage parlors, tattoo shops

status_details: Gov. Henry McMaster, a Republican, was among the last to issue a stay-at-home order and among the first to begin opening up his state, starting April 20 with retail stores. Tourist attractions reopened in time for Memorial Day weekend. But with cases rising, Mr. McMaster said he wouldn’t allow movie theaters, concerts, race tracks or nightclubs to open.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches, piers, docks, etc.; Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos, aquariums
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.

date_details: Updated guidance for businesses and residents on April 28.
status_details: Gov. Kristi Noem, a Republican, refused to issue a stay-at-home order — despite requests from local officials — and did not close businesses in the state, though she ordered them to follow C.D.C. guidelines. She invited workers and business owners frustrated by lockdowns in other states to visit South Dakota.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops

status_details: Gov. Bill Lee, a Republican, announced reopening plans for 89 of 95 Tennessee counties starting April 27. The remaining counties were to follow individual reopening plans. All counties are now in some phase of reopening, and restaurants and retail stores can operate in most counties with no restrictions.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Gyms
opened_entertainment: Theaters, museums, amusement parks
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.

status_details: Gov. Greg Abbott allowed his stay-at-home order to lapse on April 30, a move that gave Texas one of the shortest such orders in the country. A surge in cases in late June caused Mr. Abbott to order bars to close and restaurants to reduce capacity, among the first reopening reversals in the country. Starting July 3, he once again encouraged Texans to stay home and required face covering in public places in counties with more than 20 cases.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Pools; Gyms; Water parks; Zoos
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, museums, libraries; Bowling alleys, bingo halls, skating rinks, rodeos; Aquariums; Amusement parks; Carnivals
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.; Massage services

status_details: Gov. Gary R. Herbert, a Republican, started to reopen Utah by region on May 1. Now, just one county remains at “moderate risk,” and restaurants, gyms and salons are open everywhere.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Movie theatres, museums, libraries, concerts
opened_personal_care: Salons, personal care businesses

status_details: Gov. Ralph Northam, a Democrat, started reopening much of the state on May 15, but kept northern Virginia, near Washington, D.C., closed until May 28. All counties moved into Phase 3 on July 1. Mr. Northam lifted capacity limits on retail stores, restaurants and bars, but kept some restrictions on indoor seating in place.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Beaches; Gyms; Pools
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos, aquariums, outdoor concerts

status_details: Gov. Phil Scott, a Republican, allowed small changes, such as the opening of farmers’ markets, before a broader reopening beginning with retail stores on May 18. Other businesses, such as gyms and restaurants, reopened in June. Starting August 1, the face masks will be required in both indoor and outdoor public spaces.

opened_entertainment: Museums, theaters, libraries
opened_personal_care: Hair salons and barbershops; Nail salons, spas, tattoo parlors

status_details: While every county has now moved into some phase of reopening, Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, said he would pause further reopenings until at least July 28. Mr. Inslee also expanded an order to use face coverings in all public spaces starting July 25. Restaurants, gyms and movie theaters must reduce capacity in some counties.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks, fishing, hunting, golf courses
opened_entertainment: Casinos
opened_personal_care: Gyms in most counties; Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.; Pet grooming

status_details: The state Supreme Court struck down Gov. Tony Evers's stay-at-home order on May 13, effectively lifting statewide restrictions on businesses in Wisconsin. Mr. Evers, a Democrat in a highly contested battleground state, had already announced plans for a gradual reopening but warned the ruling would cause “chaos.” Some counties have since placed their own restrictions on businesses.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; State parks; Gyms
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers for curbside dropoff; Hair salons, spas, barbershops

status_details: West Virginia’s stay-at-home order was in place for a little more than a month. Gov. Jim Justice, a Republican, lifted restrictions on certain businesses on May 4, with new reopenings each following week. Starting July 7, face coverings are required where social distance can’t be maintained. The governor limited social gatherings to 25 people, ordered the closure of fairs, festivals and concerts statewide and ordered bars in Monongalia County to close starting July 14.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms, recreation centers; State parks, campgrounds; Pools

opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, pet groomers; Tanning salons; Massage parlors and spas

status_details: Gov. Mark Gordon, a Republican, did not order Wyoming residents to stay home, and he began lifting restrictions on businesses May 1. However, Mr. Gordon recently extended restrictions on restaurants, bars and gyms until at least July 31.
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; State parks
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, entertaiment venues
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.
